dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kicking off today, we're diving into some economic cautionary tales from, uh, Europe. Remember the early 2000s? Everything was booming.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kicking off today, we're diving into some economic cautionary tales from, uh, Europe. Remember the early two thousand seconds? Everything was booming.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European economy was booming, fuelled by debt in the early 2000s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, absolutely. Just, like, endless growth, especially down in Southern Europe. And, um, fuelled by a lot of debt, right? Which meant big construction projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, absolutely. Just, like, endless growth, especially down in Southern Europe. And, um, fuelled by a lot of debt, right? Which meant big construction projects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European economy was booming, fuelled by debt in the early 2000s. Southern Europe was on a resurgent growth path which meant construction projects were easily funded to cater to this expansion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Grandiose projects, easily funded. But then... the financial crisis hit. Big time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Grandiose projects, easily funded. But then... the financial crisis hit. Big time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And demand just, you know, absolutely plummeted. For everything. Travel, infrastructure investment, all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And demand just, you know, absolutely plummeted. For everything. Travel, infrastructure investment, all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Demand waned, for both travel and infrastructure investment, leaving some grandiose construction projects abandoned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Leaving behind these amazing, but completely abandoned, infrastructure projects. And one that really stands out is Ciudad Real airport in Spain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Leaving behind these amazing, but completely abandoned, infrastructure projects. And one that really stands out is Ciudad Real airport in Spain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This was the case for Ciudad Real airport in Spain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that one! The, uh, the ghost airport. So, it was meant to take pressure off Barcelona El Prat, but it was located like, 250 miles north of Madrid, which is, um, quite a distance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that one! The, uh, the ghost airport. So, it was meant to take pressure off Barcelona El Prat, but it was located like, two hundred fifty miles north of Madrid, which is, um, quite a distance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Originally designed to take excess traffic away from Madrid Barajas airport, the airfield was located a staggering 150 miles North of the city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, low-cost airlines were trying to keep prices down using secondary airports, but this was just... too remote. For passengers and airlines alike.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, low-cost airlines were trying to keep prices down using secondary airports, but this was just... too remote. For passengers and airlines alike.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At a time when low-cost airlines were keeping costs down by serving secondary airports, the remote location of Ciudad Real seemed a little too much for passengers and airlines alike to absorb.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it was open for just two years, and only, like, one airline ever flew there â€“ EasyJet. That's, uh, that's not a great sign, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it was open for just two years, and only, like, one airline ever flew there - EasyJet. That's, uh, that's not a great sign, is it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The international airport was open for just three years and saw flights from only two airlinesRyanair and Vueling...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not at all! And it just sat there, racking up costs, falling into disrepair. They even had to paint huge green crosses on the runways so pilots knew it was abandoned. Can you imagine?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not at all! And it just sat there, racking up costs, falling into disrepair. They even had to paint huge green crosses on the runways so pilots knew it was abandoned. Can you imagine?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...including having to paint large yellow crosses over the crumbling runway so pilots knew the airfield was abandoned...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, it eventually went up for sale, I remember. Started at, what, 60 million euros?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, it eventually went up for sale, I remember. Started at, what, sixty million euros?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With an initial price tag of 80 million being shunned...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, 60 million. But then, get this: in 2016, a group of Swiss investors picked it up for *five thousand euros*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, sixty million. But then, get this: in twenty sixteen, a group of Swiss investors picked it up for five thousand euros.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...that airport was eventually picked up in July 2015 by Tzaneen International, a group of British and Asian investors, for just 10,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Five thousand?! That's... that's like buying a used car! But, uh, the Spanish courts actually rejected that, saying it was too low and didn't include the terminal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five thousand?! That's... that's like buying a used car! But, uh, the Spanish courts actually rejected that, saying it was too low and didn't include the terminal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, Spains commercial court rejected the bid saying that it was too low and that the airport terminal and car parks wouldnt have been included.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it was quite the saga. Another bid fell through later that year. But it *did* eventually sell, though, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it was quite the saga. Another bid fell through later that year. But it did eventually sell, though, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Later that year, an unidentified investor proposed a 28 million bid for the airfield to the courts, however, that potential transaction also fell through.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It did! In 2019, for a much more respectable 56.2 million euros. And, uh, it saw its first flight just last month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It did! In twenty nineteen, for a much more respectable fifty six point two million euros. And, uh, it saw its first flight just last month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three years later the airport was eventually sold for 56.2 million to Ciudad Real International Airport SL in September 2018...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No passengers, though. Just a 777 landing. It's like, they're still trying to figure out what to *do* with it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No passengers, though. Just a seven hundred seventy seven landing. It's like, they're still trying to figure out what to do with it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they even tried to rebrand it as "Madrid Airport North" at one point, which is, um, a bit of a stretch when Madrid is 250 miles away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they even tried to rebrand it as Madrid Airport North at one point, which is, um, a bit of a stretch when Madrid is two hundred fifty miles away.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...with an attempt to rebrand the airfield as Madrid Airport South being halted, likely since Madrid is 150 miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Now they're looking at, like, tech support, maintenance, flight training, aircraft storage even, in that "wet, rainforest-like environment," whatever that means.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Now they're looking at, like, tech support, maintenance, flight training, aircraft storage even, in that wet, rainforest-like environment, whatever that means.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...which includes aircraft storage in the dry desert-like environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's certainly creative! But, um, the big question remains: are passengers ever really gonna want to trek that far from Madrid, especially for short-haul flights?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's certainly creative! But, um, the big question remains: are passengers ever really gonna want to trek that far from Madrid, especially for short-haul flights?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the question remains whether passengers will be willing to transit such a large distance from Madrid, particularly when flying short-haul European flights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And with Valencia potentially getting a brand new second airport soon, just 40 miles away from *its* city... Ciudad Real's future still seems, uh, pretty uncertain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And with Valencia potentially getting a brand new second airport soon, just forty miles away from its city... Ciudad Real's future still seems, uh, pretty uncertain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...there is the increasing prospect of Madrid getting a brand new second airport, just over 20 miles from the city in Casarrubios del Monte.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, time will definitely tell if this ghost airport can ever truly take off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, time will definitely tell if this ghost airport can ever truly take off.
